comments.commentBody: NOT catholic, but I love this man.  Not even religious. However, he is a vast improvement from the usual suspects.  Thank you, Holy Father,  and  I wish a very long life for you.
I left the Church long ago but find the words spoken by this leader to call me to task. I am certain it is God's work he is doing.

The Church Hierarchy of Doctrine is like the condemnation of Caifous and the high priests while Jesus was God's message of compassion to the world that endured for many centuries and inspired billions of good generous and loving people.

Thank you for being the brother of Jesus Pope Francis. Peace!

Feed the hungry. Donate to food banks and pantries. They provide good nourishing food. Many more can donate to the needy instead of the few who encounter the panhandlers. Go to them instead of waiting for a chance meeting.

It is what Jesus taught us.

This is the only way to be. The message is so simple, but because we live in a complicated world in which condescending morality and money are bedfellows, it is difficult to act with compassion on a daily basis. How sad that we need the pope to essentially say "Be a good person", and then have a newspaper editorial say "Pope To World: Be Good". But we do need that. Thank you.
What's there to worry about?  Oh, That's right, I forgot . . . Hell.  Maybe when you're pope, you feel you're beyond that.

All bishops go to Hell according to one saint who did not want to become one. One's opportunities for hellacious behavior increases with one's power and authority. Pope Francis is offer some(one) who have another example. Be generous, and stop being fearful about it. Pax, jb
Sounds good to me. Easier than having to feel bad about not doing anything.

I think Leviticus said to love ur neighbor as your self, then came Christ who said but I say Love your enemy. It is not because they are not your enemy, it is not because they are worthy even as much as your neighbor or friend is This is not the stuff that liberalism can believe in. It has little basis in reason and survival really. It answers to a higher calling.
Wonderful. Perhaps he will sell the church's art and real estate holdings to help the poor?  What? No?

Given the way he lives, I think if he could, he would. The Vatican is not his to sell or go around slapping for sale signs on it's art.
He's done far more to focus on social justice than any other modern religious leader.

No one has asked anyone here to sell their possessions and give the proceeds to the poor.

However, if you should choose to do so.......some say that there is a kingdom that awaits you.
Interesting suggestion. In the spirit of charity begins at home,  why not sell off the contents of the National Gallery or the Smithsonian? (I don't think that will fly.)
He is right.    That is all.
Every human being is a living soul and at that level, we are all equal.

Agree  one thousand percent.  I always give at least a couple of dollars.  I don't miss it,  and who am I to judge what it's used for.  Carry one dollar bills in a pocket or separate compartment. Do it, while we are still allowed to do so.
Here, and I thought, all the New York Times likes to do is trash our Catholic Brother's and Sister's! The Pope's advice is a mitvah, and so is the Times praise!
Yes, this is the Jewish ethical perspective as well!

thank you! NYT seems to think sometimes, Christians are either right-wing evangelicals or Catholics up to nostrils in Vatican intrigue. This is a hopeful sign for increased and improved dialogue. Pax, jb
Dear Pope Francis,  Thank you for being such a wonderful teacher.  Please come visit NY again because we need your compassion and grace to inspire us now.

In 2015, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker sought to scrap the state’s independent Government Accountability Board that enforces campaign finance, elections, ethics, and lobbying laws. After Koch money "won" Republicans state control, aggressive gerrymandering followed. After the 2016 election, the court ruled that Republican gerrymandering in Wisconsin was unconstitutional. Despite receiving 51% of votes statewide in 2012, Democrats won only 39 of 99 Assembly seats. In 2014, Republicans won roughly the same percentage of votes statewide, but won 63 seats, a 24-seat disparity. Wisconsin had not voted into office a Republican presidential candidate since 1984. All of Wisconsin’s major polls, in fact, predicted a Clinton win by significant margins. One has to wonder if Wisconsin's voting system was insecure or targeted by the Russians -- for the polls to achieve such statistically improbable errors. Wisconsin's top state poll predictions:
​11/06/16 - Remington Research: Clinton 49%, Trump 41%
​11/04/16 - Loras College: Clinton 44%, Trump 38%
​11/02/16 - Marquette Law: Clinton 46%, Trump 40%
​11/02/16 - Public Policy: Clinton 48%, Trump 41%
Sources: http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/wisconsin
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-wisconsin-redistricting-idUSKBN13H0SV

Wasn't it Walt Whitman who said always give alms to anyone who asks?
Good plan.
Yeah, Jesus said much earlier.
I believe that was Jesus, at least he said it first.  Matthew 5.42.

Trump lied about how many stories there are in Trump Towers.  He added about 10 I think, because he thought it sounded better.  Truth is meaningless to Trump. He lies about everything every day and then re-lies about lying. It's exhausting.  No sense trying to count the lies.

Conservative advocates like governor Walker never confront the problem with so called "states rights". Historically states rights have often meant denial of minority rights. Jim Crow is the classic example. Recently states like Indiana and North Carolina have passed laws denying segments of the LGBT community "equal justice under law". Voter I.D.laws, which are really black voter suppression laws, add to the litany of state abuses. Block grants to states are thinly disguised mechanisms to cut economic aid to the poor and disadvantaged. The refusal of most Republican governors to accept free Medicaid extensions through 2016 was despicable and a national disgrace. In 2017 minorities and the disadvantaged simply can't depend on states, especially those with Republican governors, to provide equal protection of the laws. The Federal government needs to be involved to protect minority rights.

As we will soon find out, it's not the level of government that matters. It's not Federal vs State, it's Republican vs Democrat.

It does not matter if it's at the Federal or State level, if the Republicans are in control then we have the same problems regardless.

Why not just employed the hackneyed phrase, "partisan witch hunt," and spare us all the verbiage?

Meantime, read the New Yorker piece, "Trump, Putin, and the New Cold War." That should disabuse you of the notion that the call for an investigation into connections between the Trump campaign and the Putin government is based on nothing but "unsubstantiated innuendo."

I've said it before and I'll keep saying it: Swamp Thing is dangerously unqualified to be president.

The amount of damage Swamp Thing and his inept and inexperienced hubris-laden entourage of clowns can do to our country and the world in four years will take decades to reverse, if it can be fully reversed at all. The disproved isolationist-nativist philosophy will not only not "make America great again," it will weaken us for several generations.

Populism is an albatross around conservatives' necks, and a political party rooted in populism denies the central character of a republic, whose first goal is to weaken the negative effects of populism and promote a higher purpose for the republic. Americans who voted for Trump willingly disbelieved what their lyin' eyes and ears saw and heard Swamp Thing do and say and voted for him anyway. And we're getting exactly what Swamp Thing told us we'd get, an ignorant, lying, inexperienced, angry, contemptuous populist government run amok and without effective leadership.

Congratulations. As you told us, elections have consequences. How's that working out for us so far?
They think they can get away with this things because so far they are.  I am frightened, too, Susan.  What should we do?

Mr. Walker, you and your cohort will "stand strong" against protest at your own  political peril. I'm flummoxed at how you can be so tone deaf as to mistake this moment, these protests, for simple ideological dissent.  As a 57 year old woman who has never protested in her life, I can tell you that, while I usually disagree with you politically, I have never and would never take to the streets to oppose your ideas.  Had one of the more mainstream Republican candidates won, I would have been disappointed, but I wouldn't have marched in dissent.  Can you really be so disconnected from the zeitgeist, so mesmerized by the echo chamber you clearly inhabit to fail to see that I, and millions like me are taking to the streets every chance we get because we are utterly horrified by the spectacle coming from this White House and by the Republican's 180 degree turn toward this criminal miscreant?? Can you be so compartmentalized that you do not understand the sense of overwhelming dread of this man and his cronies that the country is swimming in? You flattered yourself into thinking that you all can control this man, but we know better.  Wake up Mr. Walker. Average people like me are not going to quietly watch while our country goes down in flames. Stand strong? You need to look at who is actually showing up and speaking out and LISTEN before it's too late.
Excellent. I never protested before. But I'm also fired up. And frightened. Great comment! Thank you.

Heartily agree.  However, the Scott Walkers of this country have long used the states rights argument to camouflage their real agendas regarding social, economic and cultural issues in the service of gaining, increasing and keeping power.  Having answered "God's calling" to run for President, Walker failed early (so early that Trump didn't get a chance to give him a nickname) and miserably (never polled > 1%) in his bid for the nomination, He returned his attention to the malgovernance of Wisconsin, where he perversely expanded Medicaid per the ACA but turned down the federal taxpayer dollars ($653 million) to pay for it.  In other words, he refused the return of federal tax dollars paid by Wisconsinites and is actually costing them state tax dollars in the form of the fees the state must pay the insurance companies who administer the Medicaid program.  He also failed to publicize federal court ordered changes in Wisconsin's egregious and unjust voter ID law by not funding the necessary effort to do so, preventing an estimated 300,000 of his citizens from voting.  Wisconsin clearly needs more, not less, monitoring and regulation on the part of the United States government until it rids itself of it's homegrown "criminal miscreant".

Dear Sharon, you are my twin. I am 56 and grew up in the Heights, currently in Tampa Florida, and also disturbed and distressed. You summarized my thoughts so completely and so eloquently. Thank you, Yours in Resistance, Julia

Great idea, give the states back power over how health care is provided... and then don't give them enough funds to provide adequate services.  Gov. Walker seems perfectly happy to go back to 40 million un/underinsured. Why should he care?  He has a nice plump government insurnace policy.
Who cares if the majority of Americans don't agree with us!  Democracy doesn't matter!
Help me out here Governor Walker.  When did you take the high road again?
It’s difficult to make jeopardizing healthcare for upwards of 30 million Americans to fund tax cuts for the wealthiest sound high-minded.  But nice try anyway.

This simpleton really believes that the only ideas worth considering are those that fit his ideology.  Those that don't are contemptible if not downright treasonous.  And once again, he rolls out the mantra of Reagan.  Does his pantheon begin and end with him?
